EDIT/POST MORTEM:  As many predicted, the UN Committee deferred the request of the Taliban to replace the representative from Afghanistan. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/01/world/americas/united-nations-taliban-myanmar.html?campaign_id=51&emc=edit_mbe_20211203&instance_id=46869&nl=morning-briefing%3A-europe-edition&regi_id=77825025&segment_id=75971&te=1&user_id=dc6933c94fc82416d25dd297622374d1 Dec. 1, 2021
A bid by the new Taliban government in Afghanistan and the junta ruling Myanmar to gain international recognition suffered a blow on Wednesday when the United Nations put off a decision on the rightful representatives of both countries. The deferral by a powerful U.N. committee effectively denied, for now and possibly through much of 2022, attempts by the ruling authorities of Afghanistan and Myanmar, which are widely considered pariahs, to occupy seats at the United Nations. The nine-nation Credentials Committee of the General Assembly, which is responsible for approving the diplomatic representation of each U.N. member state, held a closed meeting on the applications by the Taliban and Myanmar junta to replace the ambassadors of the governments they had deposed. Afterward, the committee’s chairwoman, Ambassador Anna Karin Eneström of Sweden, told reporters that the panel “defers its decision of the credentials in these two situations.”
. . . 
Diplomats said the committee would make the deferral recommendation in a report to be submitted to the General Assembly next week. That could mean the question of who represents both Afghanistan and Myanmar at the United Nations may not be resolved before the next annual General Assembly gathering in September 2022. @Khalid, @GMR, @jleibowich, @ctsats, @probahilliby, @DippySkippy, @Raisinville Additional edits to correct user names:  sorry!

This question comes up 35 days, not much time and that will influence my forecasts. 
Will the Taliban present credentials? Yes, they have wanted that in the past and UN recognition would legitimize their rule. It is a small possibility that things get so chaotic and unstable that they do not get their act together to present credentials, but it appears to be a straightforward process and doable in 35 days. 
Will the credentials be accepted? Probably not. 35 days is not enough time for the Taliban to establish changed behavior from their past rule. The argument can be made that the UN would want stability and Afghanistan to not be a haven for terrorists of all kinds. It appears they cannot control ISIS and as for stability that would take time to demonstrate. Western democratic governments would also have political problems at home if they were openly in favor of a government that came to power by force, does not recognize women’s rights and other basic human rights. Middle east and Islamic dictatorships may also be leery of recognizing a government that will provide a base for terrorists. 
What I would like to know is if the previous government will make a claim as the legitimate government in exile.
